awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research:Towards Scalable and Energy Efficient Cellular IoT Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
With smart sensing devices becoming a ubiquitous part of our connected world, the need to support large-scale communication involving Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices is becoming a reality. IoT traffic needs to be carried over cellular networks as it is the primary wide-area wireless communication infrastructure.  However, the current 3GPP architecture and protocols are inefficient and difficult to scale, even if a small fraction of all IoT devices are mobile and have to be addressable/reachable through the Internet. In addition, link layer operations, traffic scheduling, and transport protocols currently in use are not well suited for typical short, periodic and bursty IoT communication patterns. This project aims to address these limitations by re-designing core operations and protocols involved in IoT data communication over cellular networks. The issues that the project will address are not only central to the efficient operation of current 3G/4G and future 5G networks, but must be solved to make the grand vision of the Internet-of-Things a reality. Through participation by industrial partners, the team will maximize the relevance and outreach of research to practice. The PIs will involve undergraduate students in their research, and integrate findings from this research into graduate courses, and encourage participation of under-represented students.

Addressing the limitations of IoT data communication over cellular networks is challenging, as it requires supporting stringent requirements on limited capability (such as low power) end-systems, and maintaining only small amounts of state in the cellular network on a per-device basis. To address these challenges, the project will investigate novel mechanisms to eliminate cellular network tunnels by leveraging the locality of typical IoT mobility patterns and the capabilities of protocols that separate location-from-identity. Second, the project will investigate cross-layer mechanisms for adaptive optimization of Radio Resource Control (RRC) configurations towards attaining an ideal balance between end-device energy efficiency and information exchange overhead in the network. Third, the project will investigate new mechanisms for efficient traffic scheduling over the air-interface. Finally, the project plans to design a new transport that can dynamically adapt based on IoT application requirements, and is flexible enough to effectively handle the varying size of data transfers. The solutions will take into account the specific properties in IoT communication.

por.por_cntn:
This project has examined how to enable IoT applications to manage energy available from sources of renewable energy and has developed a more efficient way for serverless computing to support such IoT application needs in the backend on an edge cloud. The project also analyzed the energy efficiency of existing and emerging IoT communication protocols, and developed an efficient authenticated key exchange protocol with strong security guarantees for IoT.

A significant contribution made by the project is the design of a Smart Energy Management (SEMA) solution for IoT Applications enabling them to be energy aware. The project developed a SEMA Stick hardware with multiple sensors (along with researchers in HP Labs), a single, compact, energy-aware IoT sensing and edge computing platform for video/image capture as well as environmental monitoring, particularly for agricultural applications. The SEMA solution comprises several components centered around battery management using Model Predictive Control (MPC) to optimize task parameter selection while ensuring battery charging is prioritized appropriately to allow the system to run overnight monitoring the environment. SEMA includes a task characterization component to model the energy and utility functions for each task. For this, we experimentally evaluated the energy for all the sensors and the messaging overhead, including adding encryption and authentication features at the application layer. The project experimentally evaluated the performance of IoT application protocols under varying loss, delay and disruption conditions that are typical of IoT environments. The results have analyzed IoT protocols such as CoAP, MQTT, MQTT-SN and QUIC in terms of energy and messaging overhead. We derived guidelines for identifying the most effective environment for the operation of each of these protocols, and understanding of the limitations of their dynamic range. The project also studied the impact of increasing protocol stack complexity, including the use of encryption and DTLS on top of COAP.  The protocol complexity comes with a significant energy cost, especially when using simple AES encryption and DTLS, which is more complex requiring more packet transfers. These results are useful in the SEMA smart energy management task.

A second contribution was in the use of serverless platforms for IoT applications. Serverless computing is eminently suited for supporting IoT applications because of the infrequent use of computing for performing computations and inferences based on sensor input and possibly activating devices, as needed. There are critical challenges that make it difficult to directly use existing serverless solutions such as Knative (which is built on top of Kubernetes). These include overhead from heavyweight components for managing the overall system and software adaptors for communication protocol translation used in off-the-shelf serverless platforms that are designed for large-scale centralized clouds. Using a streamlined protocol adaptor to leverage the MQTT IoT protocol in our serverless framework for IoT event processing and developing a novel, event-driven proxy based on the extended Berkeley Packet Filter (eBPF), to replace the regular heavyweight Knative queue proxy, we showed that our enhancements improves performance (especially higher throughput) and lower CPU usage.

A third contribution was the enhancement of the CleanG protocol and implementation for working with 5G. CleanG is a new packet core architecture including a significantly more efficient control-plane protocol, that exploits the capabilities of modern-day Network Function Virtualization (NFV) platforms. Additionally, the project contributed to the development of an open-source implementation of the 5G core based on the 3GPP standard, running on top of OpenNetVM.

Finally, the project designed and developed a lightweight authentication and key exchange protocol that is customized for IoT environments and devices which may have limited computing power, memory, energy, and disconnected operation, without network access to a trusted third party.  The protocol developed, Haiku provides authentication, key exchange, confidentiality, and message integrity. It is resource efficient, and works well in disconnected IoT environments.

The research on this project was done in close collaboration with our partner, Professor Koushik Kar of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. The project has led to several publications in international conferences and one journal publication. It partially contributed to the completion of one PhD dissertation at UCR. It also contributed to one Masters project.  Finally, the project has helped two other PhD students make good progress on their dissertations so far. Our theoretical and experimental results on IoT energy management will help in developing interfaces to applications to adapt to energy availability and encourage the use of renewable energy sources for a broader range of applications. The enhancements to the serverless computing for IoT will help in developing a significantly more efficient cloud computing platform for handling IoT applications.  Overall, the results from this project would help in operating IoT networks in a more secure and efficient manner given the energy limitations of the IoT devices.
